This is a design i have not test printed it the measurements are as close as possible with out having a 26650 to match it, the 18650 is pretty dead on!
theres also little dimples in the side so u can print a pin and connect them together for dual battery config. u can add + - signs to the print as needed
Needed: 20, 18 or 16gauge solid copper wire or any wire you can make a spring or pin for contacts
use a 10 to 15% fill when printing it will still need to flex to remove battery from holder if you print on a heaver fill battery might get stuck in place!
I suggest you check measurements in google skp before printing
enjoy!
-ChungPow Mike

comments.text: If I get time I'll run one off tonight. Getting tired of Keystones being sold out or being sold for 2-4 times original price. Plus quality 26650 holders being nonexistant. I'll let you know how they turn out if I manage to get to them. For contacts, keystone sells the tabs only for a buck or so available through mouser and/or digikey. Depending on the space it may need a little adjusting. Tabs allow for more contact and lend themselves better for high amp builds. Also, if you prefer DIY to the max, I buy brass strips in the hobby drawers at the local hardware store (lowes) that you can cut and make into these contacts for far cheaper. I've successfully made several, although they are not as clean cut but I'm sure they can be with a little practice.
comments.author: ChiefGeek

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bM7NN-fiMXs
In this project we're building a diy midi controller that works with ios devices and analog synths. Say hello to oontz, the open source button grid controller based on the adafruit trellis. The mini oontz is a 3d printed case housing one trellis and 4 potentiometers ideal for a 16 button drum pad making a compact music instrument. Get the tools and parts for this project from Adafruit.
Full Tutorial
https://learn.adafruit.com/mini-untztrument-3d-printed-midi-controller
Install the oontz libraries and program the arduino leonardo to make a native usb midi controller. use our demo sketches to get your oontz lit up. Learn all out midi oontz library and how you can build your owb by checking out the guide on the adafruit learning system. The 16 buttons trigger leds and midi notes that are mapped to this table in the arudino demo sketch. The potentiometers are mapped to midi cc's like modulation, expression and filter cut off. Connect it to an iOS device using the camera kit usb adapter for a mobile production setup. Use your laptop and a midi to usb interface to control an alalog synth.
For a massive midi controller, check out the hella oontz, feauring 128 buttons. Perfect for making a step sequencer or an arppegio that is hella hackable. Add Oontz to your arsenal of midi weapons. Oontz works with any midi software and hardware. No more virtual midi or serial to midi stuff, oontz is legit USB midi. What awesome sensors and features would you use to make your own custom oontz? Let us know in the comments below.

Learn all out midi oontz library and how you can build your owb by checking out the guide on the adafruit learning system.
https://learn.adafruit.com/oontz-trellis-midi-instrument

description.text:
The original model is intended to be a learning aid. I felt reversing the exhaust vanes would clearly illustrate the separate function they perform.
I have uploaded the 3 parts necessary to print the exhaust section with blades in the same direction as the compressor.
I may model the stator vanes as a part that is glued in for an even more realistic effect, if people are wanting that.
Thanks,
Patrick Saville

Inspired by the Easy as PI box (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3817) and the A-Mazing Box (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1481). The combo is as easy as PI... to 15 figures. That's 3.14159265358979

Print one of each piece. Snap Ring3 onto the Base, Ring2 onto Ring3 and Ring1 onto Ring2. The ticks are 0 to 9, so remember that 3 is actually the fourth tick, 1 is the second tick etc.  
Align the ticks to the first three digits (314) from left to right with the Base all the way to the left and the lid to the right. Advance the lid out one stage. Repeat for the next three digits and so on until the lid comes free.  
When in trouble, unsnap the Base from Ring3 to access the contents.  
Some sanding is required to get everything to fit smoothly.

comments.text: I really like this design, and attempted to print this over the weekend.  The tolerances of the rings were too tight to first be easy to "snap the rings" together and second once snapped together wouldn't turn at all.  It may work with some sanding, but it doesn't seem to be a print and put together scenario, at least with ABS.

author: Mustangoffroad

title: Robot interface for the Hanz inventor lab

description.text: The robot interface kit Includes a servo mount and a reversible servo shaft adapter. This allows you to convert the Hanz Inventor Lab into a very flexible robotic build platform. this is a work in process so you will note that the serrations inside the shaft adapter may not fit all servo shafts. If you are a school, robot club or other STEM program we have an inventory of injection molded parts that are available on a first-come first-served basis.

The servo housing can mount in particular or at a 90° angle to the construction set black brain part. This allows you to create the foundation of your robotic build.  
With the reversible shaft adapter you have the option of using the brain interface to move objects up and down for any horizontal axis such as a robot arm.  
You can reverse the shaft interface and use a continuous rotating servo to drive a car or robot.  
We find that our parts don't print perfectly on the replicator but usually they work well we're working on modifying the file to be optimized for the replicator.

Using this part may not work for everyone (or even anyone) due to length requirements for your individual situation.
Enjoy

description.text:

NOTE: Please use caution when attaching this object to your MacBook as the screen will NOT close when the holder is attached. Use at your own risk, I assume no risk if you forget to remove the holder and damage your device.

author: Beavertech

description.text:
This is a 3d topo map of the south corridor area of the Grand Canyon of the Colorado River. This map covers the area of the Village, Phantom Ranch, and the South Kaibab and Bright Angel trails.
The sample was printed using Prototype Supply PLA on a Printerbot Metal Simple. The print was finished with oil-rubbed bronze color Rustoleum spray paint and dry-brush highlighted with silver Guilder's Paste.
We talked about this finishing technique and a whole lot more about 3d printing on the 3D Printing Today podcast available on iTunes, Stitcher radio or direct from the source at http://threedprintingtoday.libsyn.com/ You can watch a video tutorial about how to make your own miniature mountains at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bzwybr65I9o
Complete instructions on how to make models from digital elevation data can be found on my blog at http://www.the3dprintedfuture.com/shapespeare/?p=1

title: Spool Rod Holder 8mm (meant for waterproof spool storage container)

description.text:
*see links below This thing is designed to be screwed into the side of a container and hold an 8mm diameter rod. We used a waterproofed storage box to hold all of our various colors of filament. The 8mm (diameter) rod sits in the holder on the wall of the container allowing the spools to spin freely. Then each different color of filament has its own port and teflon tube which it flows to and then can be fed into the print head. We also added a desiccant to soak up any water that might make its way in when the box is opened from time to time. Container

Do you vape at your desk? Keep it all organised with this handy Vape Stand!

  • Run a thin bead of Plastic Weld or similar acrylic glue along all the corners to glue it all together.
    The top shelf piece is reversed because I made it using clear acrylic and wanted to etch the underside. If using an opaque colour, swap it back so that the logo etches on the front!

This Venus Globe has all clouds removed to show an exaggerated version of Venus' landscapes. The elevations from NASA Magellan and Pioneer spececraft have some missing data, so I took the data from the Soviet Union's Venera spacecraft and filled the globe completely. The Venera data has 1 degree grid and the Magellan data is using a 1/4 degree grid. The 150 factor for exaggerated elevations makes the peaks, like Maat Mons and Skadi Mons look very tall. If those names are unfamiliar to you, just google it to see 2D pictures. Or use this 3D sculpture to educate yourself.
The pictures include the 150x and a 7x globe for comparison. On the 7x exaggeration picture, see the diagonal textured lines? They are real landforms called Textured Terrain. That is not an error.
http://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/26/us/spacecraft-s-images-of-venus-s-terrain-astonish-scientists.html
SPACECRAFT_NAME = MAGELLAN
TARGET_NAME = VENUS

PUBLICATION_DATE = 1991-12-31

Software Interface Specification"

END M.I.T. Center for Space Research The radar reflectivity rho' is computed from the sum of two
factors, rho derived from the strength of altimetry echoes, and
rhocor, a correction due to diffuse scattering that is derived from
the SAR backscatter cross-section. These parameters were taken from
the ar_rho and ar_rhocor fields of altimetry data files in the
ARCDR product. To compensate for the latitudinal error, all rho
values were multiplied by an 8th order latitude-dependent polynomial rho' = rho*(p0+x*(p1+x*(p2+x*(p3+...))))/p0 + rhocor where x = (lat-lat0)/90, lat0 = periapsis latitude (~10N), and p0 = 0.110826 p1 = -0.0135412 p2 = -0.241179 p3 = -0.0103096 p4 = 1.55816 p5 = -0.130031 p6 = -2.08811 p7 = 0.242347 p8 = 0.962462 The polynomial coefficients p0 through p8 have been adjusted to retain the same average rho at all latitudes, ignoring areas known to possess anomalous reflectivity (Maxwell Montes, Beta Regio, and Aphrodite Terra). Alan Folmsbee writes:
"I predict that standing stones will be found on Venus. The thick atmosphere slows down meteorites so they make a slow landing. The meteorites stand on the surface, intact."

The Sinusoidal data files were re-sampled to make an array of elevations. Here is the link to all data for Venus that I used:
http://pds-geosciences.wustl.edu/mgn/mgn-v-gxdr-v1/mg_3002/gtdr/sinus/
Re-sample that data so the sinusoidal projection is put into an array like Mars was.
sub resample4
{
$count_re = 0;
for ($row=1; $row<$row_max; $row++ )
{
for ($column=0; $column<$col_max; $column++ )
{
$lat = -1 ( $row - 1 - $SPECLINE + 0.5 ) / $d;
$lon = ($column + 0.5 - $PROJSAMP)/(cos($lat)$d) + $PROJ_LON_RADIAN;
$lat_deg = $lat180/$pi;
$lon_deg = $lon180/$pi;
$lat_integer = int((90-$lat_deg)$resolution);
$lon_integer = int(($lon_deg + 180)$resolution);
if(($lat_integer<=$vrow_max)&&( $lon_integer <=$vcol_max)&& ($lat_integer>=0)&&( $lon_integer>=0))
You can see the cosine function is used in the Perl program. Trigonometry is fun!

Any reason for the tons of holes?

If it was just a box it would just print with say 10% fill for the whole thing. By doing all the holes. It will create two full layers of plastic around each and every one, taking both time and money.

description.text: Based on the classic Drinking game Quarters. Rules of the Game: Player 1 goes by taking a bounce shoot with the quarter trying to land it in the tower. Three option can happen 1) Player 1 misses and the quarter is passed clockwise to players 2 and the games starts again. 2) Quarter bounces into the castle and randomly rolls to any player A) The player that the quarter rolls to has to stop the quarter from rolling only by its edge. The player cannot touch the sides of the quarter while it rolls. If the player fails to do this he must drink. If he does stop the quarter he is able to return the shot by shooting again. IF he makes it first player must drink double, if he misses pass the quarter clockwise. 3) Quarter bounces into "+" slot in the middle of the castle (1 in 100 shot), The "Castle is Sacked" and everybody has to finish there drink. Quarter tower drinking game: http://youtu.be/ORUUBT1X-jY

Mercury had half of its surface measured by the Messenger spacecraft. The 30x exaggeration factor reveals vast depression, similar to the Moon Globe 30x.
PDS_VERSION_ID = "PDS3"
/ GENERAL DATA DESCRIPTION PARAMETERS /
PRODUCT_VERSION_ID = "V1"
DATA_SET_ID = "MESS-E/V/H-MLA-4-GDR-V1.0"
PRODUCT_ID = "HDEM_2"
STANDARD_DATA_PRODUCT_ID = "MLASCIENCEGDR"
INSTRUMENT_HOST_NAME = "MESSENGER"
INSTRUMENT_NAME = "MERCURY LASER ALTIMETER"
INSTRUMENT_ID = "MLA"
MISSION_PHASE_NAME = {"MERCURY 1 FLYBY","MERCURY 2 FLYBY",
"MERCURY ORBIT","MERCURY ORBIT YEAR 2"}
TARGET_NAME = MERCURY
START_TIME = 2008-01-14
STOP_TIME = 2012-09-17
PRODUCT_CREATION_TIME = 2012-10-31
PRODUCT_RELEASE_DATE = 2013-03-08
PRODUCER_ID = MESSENGER_MLA_TEAM
PRODUCER_FULL_NAME = "DAVID E. SMITH"
PRODUCER_INSTITUTION_NAME = "NASA/GODDARD SPACE FLIGHT CENTER"
DESCRIPTION = "This data product is a shape map (radius)
of Mercury at a resolution of 21.293 km/pix by 21.293 km/pix,
based on altimetry data acquired through the Mapping Phase
by the MLA instrument. The preliminary MLA data are the source for
this data set. The ground tracks were interpolated using the Generic
Mapping Tools programs 'surface' and 'grdblend'. The map is in
the form of a binary table with one row for each
0.5 degrees of latitude, pixel registered. Map values
are relative to a radius of 2440 km.
This label describes an IMG file in the form of a binary resampling
to pixel registration.
"
OBJECT = UNCOMPRESSED_FILE
FILE_NAME = "HDEM_2.IMG"
RECORD_TYPE = FIXED_LENGTH
FILE_RECORDS = 720
RECORD_BYTES = 1440
^IMAGE = "HDEM_2.IMG"
OBJECT = IMAGE
NAME = HEIGHT
DESCRIPTION = "Each sample represents height relative to a
reference radius (OFFSET) and is generated using preliminary MLA data
produced by the MLA team."
LINES = 360
LINE_SAMPLES = 720
SAMPLE_TYPE = LSB_INTEGER
SAMPLE_BITS = 16
UNIT = METER
SCALING_FACTOR = 0.5
OFFSET = 2440000
END_OBJECT = IMAGE
/ Conversion from Digital Number to HEIGHT, i.e. elevation in meters, is: /
/ HEIGHT = (DN SCALING_FACTOR). /
/ The conversion from Digital Number to PLANETARY_RADIUS in meters is: /
/ PLANETARY_RADIUS = (DN SCALING_FACTOR) + OFFSET /
END_OBJECT = UNCOMPRESSED_FILE
OBJECT = IMAGE_MAP_PROJECTION
^DATA_SET_MAP_PROJECTION = "DSMAP.CAT"
MAP_PROJECTION_TYPE = "SIMPLE CYLINDRICAL"
MAP_RESOLUTION = 2 <pix/deg>
A_AXIS_RADIUS = 2440.
B_AXIS_RADIUS = 2440.

Thank you, Planetary Data System (PDS)

After finding lots of replicator 2 feet then realizing they would fit I decided to just reuse the concepts and create my own in Solidworks. Following the sleek clean lines and minimalist approach for the creator... And asking myself: "What would Frank Lloyd Wright do?" Square feet are clearly the only real design choice. As well as allowing the feet to keep within the perimeter of the case for those who may be inclined to slip it next to a wall.

Left as an exercise: I considered making the feet spring loaded to offer better vibration protection. My thought was put an appropriate compression spring (5/16 or 3/8" diameter?, 1"-2" long?) over the bolt, between the foot and base, and to move the nut from within the foot base to on top the base. The nut would then be tightened to load the spring accordingly, yet still allow the foot/leg to float. Getting the printer level would take more effort since height adjustment once installed is not likely possible as the nut will spin free. If anyone tries this, I would be curious to know if it worked and helped dampen the vibration.

All parts are in separate files since its much easier to combine things to print than separate multi-part STL files. Solidworks design files also included.
IMHO multi-part STL files are only useful if you want to control edits and reworks to those models; which makes such models less useful to useless

Required: (Refer to Exploded view picture)
  • 4 of 1/4" flat washer with an outside diameter that fits inside the foot.
  • 8 of standard 1/4" nut ( 4 to fasten the feet to the bolt, 4 to fasten the legs to the base pieces).
  • Optional: 8 of #4 wood screw with tapered head to fasten feet base to the printer.
  • 4 of 1/4" carriage bolt minimum length 1" and maximum 3". I recommend 1.5" long bolts which gives about 1/2" height adjustment.
    • NOTE: THE BOLTS MUST BE THREADED FOR THEIR ENTIRE LENGTH OTHERWISE THE FEET WILL NOT TIGHTEN PROPERLY. Print each of the foot base pieces and four feet. ( Front Right, Front Left, Rear Right, Rear Left, and four feet) I printed them in ABS at 100% infill, 1 shell, 0.3 mm resolution. No supports, all right side up. Note: If you have an unmodified printer, the cover for the electronics may be in the way (but I think not), if so, just notch the corners or use shorter bolts (1"-1.5" bolts). The front right foot WILL REQUIRE the shorter bolt unless you have moved the SD card slot. Clean up the parts. I recommend also drilling the feet base and feet with a 1/4" drill bit to make assembly and adjustments easier but its not required. Assemble the feet to the bolts as per diagram, then insert the nuts into the feet base and thread the bolts to the feet base. Thread them all the way.
    Each foot assembly will only fit on its corresponding corner. Before pushing them on, check the leg bolts have sufficient clearance. Gently push each leg up until it bases out. The fit should be quite snug with no risk of falling off. If not, affix using two small screws per leg. If you just want to protect the wood on the legs of the printer and do not require the adjustable feet, just print the four feet base pieces and push them on alone. You most likely do not need to put screws in to hold the feet base to the printer as they are securely held on with the just the design. If you do want to secure them with screws, you MUST drill pilot holes for the screws or you risk the wood splitting. Note: If you want to make the feet more 'grippy' and cut down on vibration, affix some rubber furniture pads to the bottom of the feet.
Toy Truck; blocky to match wooden block toys.

Printed on Maker Bot Replicator 2. Should print fine on anything with a big enough platform.  
The axles should be printed on end with a raft.   
No raft or support needed for anything else.  
The wheels do take a very, very, very long time to render from the OpenSCAD file, if you remix.

I printed the trays using alternating colors and then just let the randomization happen from the "packing" of the discs in each of the trays. I was happy with the result.
This definitely won't be the only one I will do and I can't wait till my wife gets to wear it and people ask about it and she tells the story. She cried!!

title: Apple Magsafe to Magsafe2 Cable with Converter Holder for Apple Macbook Pro 13 Inch Retina Model

description.text:
I slightly modified motoi1484's Apple Magsafe2 holder to fit my 13 inch late 2012 Macbook Pro Retina 13 inch model.
This object is to be used with a MagSafe to Magsafe 2 Converter like this:
http://store.apple.com/us/product/MD504ZM/A/magsafe-to-magsafe-2-converter
The object holds the power connector and converter very snugly.
If you use an actual MagSafe 2 power adapter with your 13 Inch Retina MacBook, please download this object instead:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:409859
Now the power connector doesn't fall out every time I move the Macbook. Thanks to motoi1484 for making the original design.
NOTE: Please use caution when attaching this object to your MacBook as the screen will NOT close when the holder is attached. Use at your own risk, I assume no risk if you forget to remove the holder and damage your device.

number_of_planets = 6

This is a pet door for use inside the house for cats, small dogs, etc. It's great for allowing a small pet to escape a larger one or to keep larger pets from eating their food. The opening size is 7.75" high by 6.5" wide (196mm x 165mm). All parts can be printed except for a short length of coat hanger wire to act as part of the hinge. The door swings freely in both directions but you can install magnets at the bottom to limit its swinging. Recommend mounting the door 3 to 4 inches above the floor for all but the shortest of pets (e.g. kittens).
The front door frame slides into the telescoping rear door frame for a snug fit on doors of a variety of widths without glue, nails or screws; but there are 4 places for self-tapping screws to prevent the frames from falling out. For a version that is suitable for passing through walls, check out Pitcherj's remix at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:805527

The door and frame were printed in Natural-tone ABS at 0.3 mm resolution (Low) on my Makerbot Replicator 2X. I had rafting disabled but supports enabled to support the hinges. I used 4 shells to guarantee a fairly solid tube for the hinge. Frame pieces were printed frame face down. The frames were split in two halves to accommodate the size. You'll need to print two halves of the rear frame though only one .stl file is provided.
Recommend just installing the frame for a couple of days to get your pet used to the idea of a portal in the door. Then, install the door and coax your pet through it a few times; they'll get the idea!

description.text:
The Z Axis screws just kind of hang out in the open on the Makerfarm Prusa i3v, just waiting for something to snag and bend them. These end caps protect them from that. They are made to pressure fit 625 size bearings, which I had laying around from my ShapeOko. The left side protector replaces the bottom plate of the spool holder, as you can see in the picture.
8/14/14: Added STL files without opening for bearing, since it doesn't really need the bearings, and most people won't have bearing this size laying around
As I'm and just starting in 3D modeling, I made the right side with Designspark mechanical, and the right side, with the spool holder plate with OpenSCAD.

description.text:
Here are a few simple tags to help keep your different gas-mix ratios apart. I have included tags of 32:1, 40:1, 50:1, and even 16:1 for older engines. (I'm looking at you, Maytags!)
NOTE ABOUT PLASTICS AND GASOLINE:
I placed scraps of PLA and ABS into a jar of gasoline and let them sit. After 48 hours, the ABS was a pile of goo and while PLA seemed unaffected. Since these tags may come in contact with gas or gas fumes, I would highly recommend PLA or possibly Nylon(?). REVISION: Added 100:1 and SMOKE tags.
I started with the darker blue, cut the filament at the half-way point, and fed in white to finish off.

title: wire harness for shapeoko 2 stepper motor wires

description.text:
The stepper motor wires that run from the X-axis bracket to the Y-axis bracket need to be kept from drooping down onto the workspace or into the gantry as the tool moves across the beam.
These two parts keep the wires neatly out of the way and allow easy tension control. A couple of the images are rotated 90 degrees and the top image was cropped in the main view so the Y bracket is cut off, but you can see the full image if you click on it to open the viewer. Don't know why the images are rotated, as they are upright in my gallery, but I am unable to get them to upload in the correct orientation. Hope that is not too confusing. You can see the images displaying correctly on the shapeoko forum:
http://www.shapeoko.com/forum/viewtopic.php?f=11&t=3899

Print the two parts. Mount on the X and Y brackets, as shown in the photos. I used M5 12mm bolts for mounting, placing them through the available holes (in the Y bracket) and slot (in the X bracket).
Next route the wires, as shown. By leaving some slack in the wires as they run down the part on the Y-axis, you have some ability to change the tension in the wires easily.
If the holes are too small to allow the wires through easily, just drill them out to be bigger, so that there is no pressure on the wires.
Use tie-wraps to neaten things up.

title: Quick Release DW660 Dust Shoe (vertical pipe version)

description.text:
Remixed from Funi's design. This version is designed to attach a 1" Schedule-40 PVC pipe vertical, and then attach the vacuum hose at the other end of the PVC near the top of the router.
The "with supports" file also includes supports inside the tube, which may be slightly difficult to remove.
7/30/2014: Printed successfully using a 3mm brim setting. Got most of the internal support removed with a screwdriver and a small file.

Turn on "brim." I used 3mm. edit 3/3/2016: Part is modeled in inches. If it looks tiny, scale by 2540%.
edit 4/15/2017: Added .prt files. Can only be opened with student version of Creo.

comments.text: I printed this out today and gave it a whirl. It did a decent job and picks up 80% of the dust or so. I may cut up a 2-litre bottle and tape around the edgese to keep the rest contained and suck up. I had to sand just a little bit to the inside of the hose connector to fit my shopvac and I put a strap around the hose and the Dewalt to keep it straight. If it bobs a bit, it jiggles loose a little, but didn't fall off after an hour.
comments.author: jeremypettit

comments.text: secretspy, Thanks for the cool part -- what scaling should I use for this?   As shown in the Thingiview preview, the model is less than 1cm in size, and that's how it loads in Slic3r and Craftware for slicing.
comments.author: Shadamus

comments.text: Sounds like Slicer and Craftware are assuming millimeters, but I modeled the part in inches.  Scale by 2540% (25.4mm in an inch) and you should be good to go.  This is a fairly common occurrence with 3D models.  The 3D printing community seems to like mm but I like inches because of my background in engineering in the U.S.
comments.author: Shadamus

Simple Sponge Filament Filter for the Makerbot Replicator 2

• Print the Cap, Body, and Guide Tube
  • Glue the guide tube to the bottom of the body (CA glue)
  • Cut a 1cm cube from a kitchen sponge
  • cut a slit in the cube to allow the filament through (from any edge to the center)
  • insert the sponge into the cavity in the body
  • screw cap onto body (I used hex cap M3 8mm screws)
    • NOTE:
    I added a some painters tape to the outside of the guide tube to allow for a snug fit into the extruder. I also uploaded the Inventer Fusion files so feel free to change the design to fit your needs.

comments.text: By the way... thanks jarzayus for sharing this practical design! :)
comments.author: CreativeTools

comments.text: What does a filament filter do?,,
comments.author: TarlSS

comments.text: It also helps in some cases to lubricate the filament before it enters the extruder. Fixes some very odd "jam issues". Simply drop a few drops of oil on the sponge.
comments.author: TarlSS

comments.text: It wipes off any dust that may have clung to the filament. This helps prevent nozzle clogs due to dust buildup.
comments.author: TarlSS

title: Dust Shoe for Rigid R2401 router

description.text:
This is a Dust show for the Rigid R2401 trim router. This is the router that my CNC machine uses. The dust shoe has a hole for a standard shop vac hose for dust collection duties.  
This dust shoe uses a 30mm bolt and nut to secure the shoe to the router. I think it is a m4 bolt and nut.  
This shoe can be printed on a 12x12 cm print bed, it was designed so that my thingomatic can print it.  
I would suggest ABS be use and not PLA,  
I may do another shoe that incorporates magnets to secure the shoe to the router.

A variation of the RigidBot Z-stop Adjustment Screw by mikedifilippo This one uses a short 5mm x 8mm flathead screw and 4mm x 8mm button head screw. The range of adjustment of this design is very limited, only a few millimeters, but works with my setup, which uses a 1/8" polycarbonate plate on top of the build plate. I'm not sure how it would work if printing directly on the build plate.

title: Motor mounts for ifootage shark and extended slider

description.text:
This design is obsolete. I have a new updated version here: http://www.tmophoto.com/shop/shark-slider-motor-brackets-stl/ This is a bracket and a few pulleys that you can use to motorize your ifootage shark slider http://goo.gl/ACu7xH (amazon link for slider)
You will need a 50 tooth belt that costs about 6 bucks on amazon, I got a few of these : Gates 100XL037 PowerGrip Timing Belt, Extra Light, 1/5" Pitch, 3/8" Width, 50 Teeth, 10" Pitch Length.
http://goo.gl/yhDjOv (amazon link)
One stepper motor or a DC motor.
To make this work with a stepper motor I recommend the Emotimo TB3 controller with wireless remote for full control and repeatable moves. http://www.emotimo.com
For a basic system you could order a Dynamic Perception DC motor, add in a potentiometer in line to the power source and it will move fast or slow.
http://www.dynamicperception.com/EZ-Swap-DC-Motor-p/dp-dcm.htm
Third option is to dig into your junk drawer from three years ago and grab one of the original makerbot Kysan DC motors. These were used in the first few versions of makerbot cupcakes.
A battery to power it all the Anker astro 20k mah is a pretty nice one.
http://goo.gl/HLwKZe (amazon link)

Print out all the parts and use the hardware that comes with the slider to put it all on.
You will need 2 M3 screws and nuts for the drive gear set screws
4 screws and washers for the motor mount.

comments.text: Any news?
comments.author: GooDween

comments.text: Hi Zgbot, i 3d print one part, but can you add the file of the base plate of the motor? Like others i try to talk with Ifootage to sell me the base for the motor but they refuse off course.
comments.author: Adel079

comments.text: What an exciting project! I have a Shark S1 too, and I'm going to buy an Emotimo TB3 soon for 3-axis automation. I was actually given this link by Brian from Emotimo... how cool are they?!?
comments.author: davidahn

comments.text: I think these are best made from aluminum.  all of the plastic prototypes i have made have introduced flex and some have broken.  You cannot couple a motor directly to the shark slider because the coupler that is attached to the shaft is not straight on the sliders.  there is a slight wobble on and it puts a huge amount of stress on the motor and mounting brackets.
comments.author: davidahn

comments.text: Thanks, zgbot.
comments.author: zgbot

comments.text: I use a single 4s battery to power the TB3, aux motor driving the slider and my camera.  I have a 12v dc/dc converter going to the TB3 and another dc/dc converter at 7.8v for the battery (canon with no grip)  the less weight you have on the tb3 the better.
comments.author: davidahn

comments.text: So for now, still happy with the TB3 if it would work properly with the Shark slider? I'm about to place my order for one after a little bit of last minute waffling.
comments.author: zgbot

comments.text: Absolutely.  its by far the best and easiest to set up motion controller on the market.  I have mine working with the shark slider and have been using it for a few months I just think the mounting brackets could be better.  I dont want to put out crappy parts that will fail during a timelpase.  nothing worse than equipment failures when you put in the time to get a shot..  I have also been using mine to do panning focus pulls while moving on the shark slider.  its an amazing little box that can do so much.
comments.author: davidahn

comments.text: Hey zgbot, any news on your end? I did buy the TB3, but Shark refused to sell just the motor mount. So I guess we're on our own. I'm going to see how much it costs to have your part machined out of aluminum. I'll try to get two sets. Any refinements to your design before we commit it to metal? Or is plastic the only real weakness as far as you can tell?
comments.author: zgbot

comments.text:
I also contacted shark manufacturer, and they also deny to give me any info or parts, only whole unit.
So i am also ready to buy)
comments.author: davidahn

comments.text: BTW, placed the order last night. Can't wait! Oh wait, I have to wait until I have a way to mount the motor!
comments.author: zgbot

comments.text: Thanks for all your help, zgbot. I'm really impressed with the Shark S1, it's really nice and smooth. I'm really happy with my choice of slider, but I can't wait to get it motorized!
comments.author: zgbot

comments.text: Hello, Any news?

comments.text: I would not recommend using DC motors with a setup like this, they are far less accurate and you will need to add end stops to the slider so you dont crash the camera sled into the end.  all of the mounting holes for the DP motors are the same as the stepper motors that i have so it should work once i have it all finished.  but you will have to be extremely careful.  you can easily destroy your belt if you let the cart run into the end of the slider.

I wanted to observe and record my creations on my MakerBot Replicator, so I bought a Logitech C525 Webcam. The problem was finding a good place to mount it with a good viewing angle. I enclosed my MakerBot Replicator with an acrylic box on top (with corner blocks I designed and which I will post later) and panels on the front and sides, using these panel holders: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:27895 and http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:27865. Then I came up with the idea of mounting this platform I designed in SketchUp to the front acrylic panel.

When building, I used the Replicator's Accelerated Defaults and upped the heated bed temperature to 118 C.
After several wrapped ABS prints, I designed the platform with little "mouse ears" in each of the corners of the platform for better adhesive to the bed. Trim these ears after printing.
Lay the platform perpendicular to the front acrylic panel where you would like mount the webcam platform and mark the drill holes on the front panel.
Drill holes to accomodate a M5 bolt. I recommend using a stepper drill for this, cleaner cut.
Bolt the platform to the front panel with two M5x10mm bolts and nuts. You may need to enlarge the bolt holes on the platform with an appropriately sized drill bit.
Simple compact flash storage. First design

Adapter mount to securely and easily fix flashlights to a tripod for beamshots shooting.
Easy to assemble (just 4 parts), fixes just in place for a tripod. Use a rubber band or a Velcro tie to fix the flashlight.

title: Tron Dual Extrusion Light cycle Keyring
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Not hard to print at all. Load 1 piece into your slicer, do not move it anywhere. Load the second piece - then if you need to center them or move them,move them together. They are already flat on the build plate at 0,0,0 so really, you should just be able to load them both without needing to move or rotate them. I was watching Tron again the other night (both of them..) And I thought to myself, man.. why haven't I made a glowing Tron thing... I have everything I need right here.. So here we go! Now, I will put a few comments in the instructions so please read those if you either want to print this out or to modify it, as you can't right now as it's still a work in progress (i mean you can print it, you can't remix it yet) there are alot of makes I created around this theme which I was going to release in a pack, but I'll see if anyone wants the stuff first before I upload the big thing. Which is?
---read instructions...
p.s see the black ABS I'm using? it's junk. If anyone knows of good Black PLA or ABS that has a very high tolerance I would highly appreciate a link! :)

description.text: A pixelated cursor keychain - not yet test printed. The current scale makes it a little longer than 2".

Ball mount (shown with Vise Clamp posted by cgongora69) http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:186545
Provides a stable base for a variety of vises or clamps could be used to mount a small camera also.

Made in 3 pieces to avoid need for supports and make assembly easier
Recommended material: ABS.
Set raft and supports off for all pieces.
Set infill for base and vice mount to 30%
Set infill for Ball Clamp to 60%
Print all 3 parts.
Drill and tap for 6-32 screws in the bottom of the vice or clamp you wish to mount. Bolt pattern is 10mm X 30mm on center.
Attach the "vice mount to your vice with 6-32 screws
The ball on the base may require a bit of light sanding, but keep it light or the clamp may not hold well.
Snap the Ball Clamp onto the ball on the base. (a few drops of Isopropyl alcohol will make it slip on readily)
Install a washer on a 6-32 X 1.25" screw and insert into the ball clamp. Install a washer and wing nut, level the top of the ball clamp and tighten to lock in place
Glue the vice mount assembly to the top middle of the ball clamp allow to dry for at least an hour.
. Mount can be screwed to a small board or work bench or glue a sheet of rubber gasket material to bottom for non-slip desk top use.

title: Z thrust bearing mount for Loches upgraded MG Prusa

description.text: This is kind of an ugly hack to make the nice coupling system from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16263 work with a MG Prusa that had Loches Z axis upgrade http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:22887 applied. Basically, I de-integrated it a bit. Works great except that the rods no longer reach the lower constraint. I recommend printing a new lower z-axis stabilizer before mounting these. Poor print quality was from a botched slic3r config on my part, but it works...

Print, replace the top motor mounts with these.  See "parent" thing for more detailed instructions - you'll need some long M3 screws and a pair of 608 bearings.
Update: I recently switched my bearings to some 22mm outer, 1/4 inch inner "extended inner" bearings I found from VXB.  It's odd they have the two different measurement systems, but it's exactly what I needed for this.  22mm outer fits in the holes made for 608 bearings, but 1/4 inch inner fits my ACME lead screw.  And the extended inner section means that the bottom constraint actually does just reach.
Adjust, adjust, adjust!  It really does make a big difference in print quality if you have wobble in one or both of the z leadscrews...

comments.text: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16263 is not found, are you just referring to the flexible metal couplings? By the way, love your Z-axis upgrade, my Prusa is printing better than ever :)
